statement.text: Vascular closure devices (VCDs) are mechanical systems designed to achieve hemostasis at arterial access sites, allowing faster patient ambulation and reduced compression time compared to manual compression. Major device categories include collagen-based (AngioSeal), suture-mediated (Perclose, ProGlide), and staple/clip-based (StarClose). Device selection depends on arteriotomy size, patient anatomy, anticoagulation status, and planned use (diagnostic vs interventional). Understanding device mechanisms, proper deployment, and complication management is essential.
statement.formal: VCD Categories: Collagen-based (AngioSeal) - intravascular anchor + collagen plug | Suture-mediated (Perclose/ProGlide) - percutaneous suture deployment | Clip-based (StarClose) - extravascular clip | Selection: Device rated for sheath size, assess CFA suitability, consider anticoagulation | Benefit: Faster ambulation, reduced compression time

explanation.intuition: Vascular closure devices are like different types of patches or stitches for the hole left after removing a catheter from an artery. Some devices plug the hole with a sealant (collagen), some sew it closed from the inside (suture devices), and some clip it from the outside (staple devices). The goal is the same - stop the bleeding faster than just pressing on it - but each device has its own way of doing it.
explanation.key_insight: Device selection should match the clinical scenario. Suture-mediated devices (Perclose/ProGlide) are the most versatile - they work with anticoagulation and can close large arteriotomies (up to 21F using 'preclose' technique). Collagen-based devices (AngioSeal) are reliable for standard 5-8F access. Understanding which device to use when is as important as knowing how to deploy it.
explanation.technical_details: Device Types and Mechanisms: (1) Collagen-based (AngioSeal): Intravascular biodegradable anchor positioned inside artery, collagen plug deposited on top, suture connects them and compresses vessel wall. Dissolves in 60-90 days. Sizes: 6F and 8F. (2) Suture-mediated (Perclose ProGlide): Deploys monofilament sutures percutaneously. Device enters artery, footplate deploys, needles pass suture through arterial wall, suture retrieved and tied extravascularly. Can be used for 'preclose' technique for large-bore access. Size: Up to 8F (single device), up to 21F+ (preclose with multiple devices). (3) Clip-based (StarClose SE): Extravascular nitinol clip crimps arteriotomy edges closed. Does not enter vessel lumen. Size: Up to 6F. Deployment Technique (Perclose example): (1) Maintain wire access; (2) Remove sheath; (3) Insert device over wire; (4) Advance until blood return from side port; (5) Deploy footplate; (6) Engage needles; (7) Retrieve suture tails; (8) Remove device; (9) Advance knot with pusher while applying traction.
common_misconceptions: All closure devices are the same - each has different mechanisms, indications, and limitations
VCDs can close any arteriotomy - each device is rated for specific sheath sizes
VCDs are safer than manual compression - similar complication rates, but different types
You can use VCDs in any CFA - disease, calcification, and prior closures affect success

definitions_glossary.vascular_closure_device: Mechanical device for achieving arterial access site hemostasis
definitions_glossary.preclose_technique: Deploying sutures before sheath insertion for closing large-bore access
definitions_glossary.suture_mediated: Device deploying sutures percutaneously to close arteriotomy
definitions_glossary.footplate: Component of suture device that positions inside artery

indications: Large-bore access closure (TAVR, EVAR using preclose)
contraindications: Severe CFA disease/calcification at access site
Prior closure device at same site (relative - depends on device)
Access significantly above or below CFA

angioseal_6f_8f.limitations: Intravascular component, can't use at same site for 90 days

perclose_proglide.advantages: Works with anticoagulation, no intravascular foreign body remains
perclose_proglide.limitations: Learning curve, higher failure rate in calcified arteries

starclose.limitations: Smaller size range, permanent metallic implant

steps: Obtain initial access with small sheath
Leave sutures untied, secured outside skin
Tie pre-placed sutures to close arteriotomy

general_principles: Confirm CFA puncture (not SFA, profunda, or above ligament)
Assess for disease/calcification at access site
Maintain wire access until hemostasis confirmed
Hold pressure for 5 minutes after device deployment
Assess for hematoma, pseudoaneurysm before discharge

complications.management: Manual compression, adjunctive device, surgical repair if needed

complications.prevention: Don't deploy into diseased vessel, confirm position

complications.management: Antibiotics, may need device removal and surgical repair

complications.prevention: Confirm complete closure, hold pressure after deployment
complications.management: Ultrasound-guided compression, thrombin injection, surgical repair

outcomes.complication_rate: Similar to manual compression in most studies
outcomes.patient_satisfaction: Higher with VCDs vs manual compression

learning_objectives: Describe the mechanisms of major vascular closure device categories
Select appropriate closure device based on clinical scenario
Perform VCD deployment with proper technique
clinical_pearls: Perclose/ProGlide is the most versatile - works with anticoagulation and large-bore access
AngioSeal leaves an intravascular component - can't use same site for 90 days
Preclose technique = deploy sutures BEFORE the big sheath, tie AFTER
Device failure isn't rare (3-8%) - always be ready to convert to manual compression
Proper patient selection is as important as proper technique
